comments.commentBody:
A strange man chasing a woman in the forest is not the same thing as courtship or sex.

How do you not get that that behavior would be threatening to women in the real world, outside a propagandist film?

I'm pretty sick and tired of men--all men, of every ethnicity--that hear people like Donald Trump or about athletes assaulting women, men catcalling or chasing after women, and discuss it as "sex". Sex implies mutual consent. There is plenty of disgust for consensual interracial sex, and yes, the film is offensive because it implies black men can only express their "sexuality" through predation sullying whiteness.

The behavior you're describing is that of a predator, not benign "sexuality" you're attempting to defend. None of which justifies the film and the conflation of black men with rape.

In a civilized election, yes. But how can I respect Trump when he loves stirring up trouble -- encourages his supporters to holler "lock her up!", pushed the Obama birther garbage, wants to openly stigmatize Muslims, declares that a judge with a Mexican background can't judge fairly?

This isn't simply an honorable disagreement about how to achieve sane, laudable goals. It's genuine nastiness at a whole different level.

I'm a "red letter Christian," and I agree completely with what you say about evangelical Christianity. I'd also add that, as an educated Christian, I can "win" any religious argument with an evangelical by quoting Jesus. But it makes no difference at all to them. Invincible ignorance.

It always annoys me, a tolerant atheist, when my fellow atheists blame religion. Since history began, 90% of people are religious in one way or another.

What is this so-called Christian religion? It's relevant to Mr. Orner's problem. I spent nearly a decade as a deeply committed Christian in a progressive Christian community (several, actually) seeking as best I could to understand why I was there and what it meant.

I read the Gospels over and over, and came to love Isaiah, which is beautiful poetry. There are, of course, the psalms, hymns, music, art, and a lot of community outreach (soup kitchen and other ways of helping people, visiting the sick, mentoring and just plain enjoying life).

These activities I assume would be normal for any church. But what is puzzling is the flat out stubborn ignorance about what we know about the life of Jesus as represented in the Gospels. (I never cared much for Paul, but he's not all bad.) The Jesus of the Gospels contradicts what these so-called evangelicals, particularly those who support Trump, appear to believe.

The Gospels are short and repetitive, and there is no mistake about the message. It is not a message that says you should hate anyone, or exclude anyone, or hurt anyone, or that wealth is a sign of god's favor and poverty a sign of rejection.

The salespeople who say different are simply not Christian. They are exploiters.

The ecstasy at Trump meetings looks religious. We all want leadership, but he is just a con man.

Within the context of American politicians and their behavior, there simply is no evidence that Hillary Clinton is particularly untrustworthy.  In fact, a look at Politifact shows that her level of honesty is slightly higher than noted "truth-teller Bernie Sanders".  And to accuse someone with Clinton's record to be untrustworthy in a race defined by the absurd level of mendacity embodied by Donald Trump is not only ridiculous, but also extremely lazy intellectually.
It makes me sad to no end that Joe Biden did not enter the race; he or Bernie would have made this democrat proud to pull the lever for either. What a mess we now have thanks to Clinton.

A few months ago Democrats were falling all over him because he exonerated Hillary, sort of. Now he is a partisan Republican hack.

And a few months ago Republicans were saying he was a Democratic hack. Now they are falling all over him because he has put Hillary in a bind.

All depends on which side you're on, and that's a serious problem for our country. It's one thing to have this or that prescription for what ails the country depending on your political philosophy. It's quite another to base a whole election, a whole political system (as has been the case the last eight years) on who is in or running for office (Obama, Clinton, Trump) instead of what they stand for. Mr. Trump insisted that we view him as the best candidate not because of what he would do (which he was very vague about or waffled on) but on who he was. Unfortunately, we bought into this, whichever side we are on. Because the voters don't want to get into policy details and their likely outcomes, Ms. Clinton too saw this approach as the easiest and surest path to victory: focus on Mr. Trump's personality and temperament, unsuited for office. How many people, even Hillary supporters, can recite her position on Syria? How would she tweak the ACA to make it work better? How is that different from what Trump would do in replacing the ACA? Now, do you know the name of the Miss Universe he dissed and what his criticism of her was? What did Hillary say about that? See? That, you know.

I don't know Mr. Comey's motivations nor does anyone else. A few months ago Democrats were falling all over him because he exonerated Hillary, sort of. Now he is a partisan Republican hack. A few facts..he was appointed by George Bush but Barack Obama has kept him in his job for nearly 8 years. Mrs. Clinton put the private server in her basement and this is not the same as using Gmail or Yahoo as Mr. Powell and a few others did. Carlos Danger, aka Anthony Weiner, is under investigation and some Clinton emails were discovered on his wife and his computer and devices. A graphic in today's paper outlines the tortured release of emails by the Clinton Camp. Not a great record of transparency.

All of these are facts not conspiracy theories. In classic Clinton fashion the attack squad begins against Mr. Comey. Soon we will learn that 25 years ago he made an unwanted advance on someone, watches XXX rated movies, and is a sociopath. This is the Clinton way. However the facts remain that she brought this on herself. She should be 40 points ahead of Trump but is clearly not considered trustworthy except, apparently, by many of the commenters at the NYT.
Sort of like Loretta Lynch and Bill Clinton meeting on the tarmac just before the release of Comey's report. Of course they were just discussing their grandchildren....
Hillary doesn't want press conferences because she doesn't want to ask questions. You don't have to like Trump to dislike Hillary.

Edward, there have been EIGHT investigations into Benghazi and they have turned up nothing. Either the committee is pathetically inept or there really is nothing there. I believe the latter: there is nothing there, but they keep trying because they're doing a smear campaign.

The family of Christopher Stevens emphatically does not blame Hillary or anyone in the Obama administration: http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/chris-stevenss-family-dont-blame...

@ Girish Kotwal
Before making his announcement Comey should at least have had some clue as to what was in the emails. Perhaps they were just innocent emails between Mrs. Clinton and her aide and not classified emails. Comey's "big reveal" created lots of noise which may affect the election, coming so close to the election date. He may not look at the emails until after the election. Comey's actions are irresponsible, lacking judgement or perhaps showing his true Republican colors.
The article is about the 20 World Series Tyler Kepner has attended. First in 1983, another in 1993, and then 18 after that. He did not attend the 1989 series.
The essay is about World Series games the writer saw in person. Apparently he watched the 1989 series like most of the rest of us - from his couch on TV

It does not whether security was compromised. Hillary intentionally by passed the official state dept server. It's the same as if someone drove for four years without car insurance and said well I did not get into any accidents. It's the sheer recklessness of not having insurance   . Hillary is not fit for dog catcher much less president.
I anxiously await the follow-on article about the underrepresentation of white males in the NFL and NBA players' ranks.

I know the New York Times would like it to be about race, but it isn't. Dusty Baker, for example, has been a Major League manager for 21 seasons, with little success, his race notwithstanding.  Frank Robinson managed in the big leagues for 16 seasons, winning nothing.  What do they have in common with many other long time managers of all races?  They're baseball lifers, long time members of the "good old boy" club (membership not restricted by race) and most importantly, men who know how baseball works.

I'm sorry, but latching on to this whine is a bit silly. Looking for problems where there is none. There have been and there will be managers of color. Managing is not the same as playing. What's next? How come there are no Chassidic managers? Moslem managers? Syrian managers? Asian/Japanese managers? How about women managers? Find a different thing to whine about...like how come in basketball there are not enough Latin managers or in hockey there are not enough little people managing. Give me a break.

Powell makes a strong case. But here's a couple of things that struck me as I read - neither detracting from the argument he makes:

Powell says C. Counsell was a "nice enough" infielder - that's quite the Obamaesque put down, as in "Hillary, she's likeable enough", though Counsell played 16 years in the Majors and had some thrilling successes- something very few players do.

Powell also questions the Latino roots of one of the people in pipe-line. That quip reminded me of Senator Warren's claims to a Native American heritage. Maybe the gentleman characterizes himself as Hispanic so that he (in baseball), like Warren (in academia and politics), can get some notoriety and a boost in a very competitive business.

All that said, certainly baseball can pull as many mediocre managers from the minority pool as it can from the white. MLB might even find a genius or two.
Someone like Francona who knows that the best time to use your best reliever is when you really need him, not when "the book" says he "should" be used.
Sorry not to see more mention of Pulisic here. Easily the most promising player the US has produced. Recorded an impressive assist against Real Madrid in Champions League.
A bit like Southampton then !

"We do not see ourselves as a selling club." -Michael Zorc, as three starters were sold in Hummels, Mkhitaryan (now in the Specially Mercenary Witness Protection Program) and Gundogan hit the door. If Pulisic, Mor and Dembele all flower as they are appearing poised to do, that could lead to future sales of Schurrle, Kagawa and even Gotze.
The defense is still a work in progress. In order for the great counterattacking potential to come to fruition, the defense needs to be much more solid. Already six points adrift of Bayern, and behind early season upstarts Energy Drink Leipzig, Koln and Hertha, they already are at a crucial juncture where they're going to have to beat bitter rival Schalke going into the return, home to Sporting Clube.
Tuchel has to get his teams right for both matches, neither of which look to be a layup.

Like many of the Republicans who refuse to disavow their support for Trump, putting party loyalty and survival above country, Mr Comey clearly values his reputation more than the traditions and practices of the Justice Department.

Since he likely won't resign, he ought to be fired. This mess is stinky enough; a little more flap over firing a rogue FBI director won't make it stink much more.

News Flash: FBI Director James Comey is rumored to be the favorite to become Dean of Students for the Republican School of Dirty Tricks. He first caught the SDT’s secret committee’s attention when he publicly spanked Hillary Clinton last July, when announcing that no charges would be recommended against Clinton regarding her handling of classified emails. Republicans expressed public hostility towards Comey for not recommending charges. Privately they were somewhat succored by the chastisement Comey issued and it was whispered that "SDT committee members saw potential in Comey". They reportedly became convinced in Comey’s value with his recent announcement that the FBI would be investigating emails Huma Abedin sent from her disgraced husband Anthony Wiener’s computer, for possible ties to the Clinton email investigation. SDT members are alleged to have been overheard making references to the movie Godfather Two. Parallels were drawn between movie character Hyman Roth boasting to Michael Corleone that their syndicate now owned their own Third World Country -Cuba in the movie; Red State America in real life- and that the day was coming for them to see their own candidate elected for President.

I hope you have a friend in need to help you as you do to yours.

PS: Oddly, I notice now I can't type in the comment box unless I check ok for notification. Of course, I uncheck before submitting, so nyah nyah.

Deadline, If I had read your comment first, it would have saved my typing the almost identical reaction to the puzzle that I had.
I join your throng of well-wishers; it is better to stay inside because of weather than because of illness. Fortunately, our snow of Thursday (100 miles north of NYC) was followed by overnight rain; and it all was gone the next morning.
I am the computer, Dave ... er I mean Rich.  Would you like to hear a song I know?

Not only was this puzzle not in my wheelhouse, I felt as if there was a sign on it saying Deadline Not Welcome.

Remarkably, I got the theme, such as it was, pretty early. Fairly recently there was a puzzle entry clued with reference to a MAC OS, and I didn't understand it until some WPer (MTFT I think) explained it. So after I saw the LION and the TIGER, along with the beginning MAC, I figured maybe MAC had taken to naming its OSs after big cats. (I have pretty much avoided having to use MACs since c. 1999-2000, and I didn't know that the MAC people had found some reason to give their OSs cutesy names. Even if I used a MAC regularly, I doubt I'd have had any interest in learning those names. Ick.)

But even more off-putting was the overwhelming number of entries clued with reference to pop music, most of which I'd never heard of. It really felt as if solvers over the age of about 25 should just go tend to their knitting. And CHEETAH GIRLS managed to hit both inside MAC and inside pop music at the same time.

I've been rather ill for the past couple of days and not up to doing puzzles. I eventually did the Thursday, Friday, and Saturday puzzles, and did get around to reading Deb's and Jeff's columns, but haven't yet caught up on reading the comments. So it'll be too late for me to add my bit. I do hope that hasn't destroyed anyone's day!

I hope everyone else enjoyed this puzzle more than I did.

Comey has provided a perfect rationale for President Obama to pardon Clinton and anyone else involved in the whole email kerfuffle before he leaves office in January.  It's clear that the FBI can't be impartial with Comey as Director, so a pardon is the only sure way to put this entire hot mess forever to bed.
That's not an interpretation. It's speculation.
except there's no evidence for your interpretation

Yeah.  Would be more willing to go along with that if David Petraeus, who knowingly took clearly marked classified information home with him to share with his mistress/biographer didn't just receive a fine and a slap on the wrist.  He's now making the rounds as a political pundit, while some still float his name as a future presidential candidate.  He wasn't even reduced in rank, and is collecting retirement benefits.  When he's doing hard, long prison time for HIS crimes, I'll start to worry about Hillary committing crimes.  Where is the outrage over his crimes . . . I don't remember it being an 18+ month dragged out affair.  Oh, that's right, his name isn't Clinton, and he's a white male.

"Listen, Clinton made an awful decision in setting up a private email server, then compounded that error by dragging her feet through defensive non-apologies that gave the story such legs. Now she limps to the finish line when she should be hitting full stride."

That's one interpretation. Another is that Hillary has genuinely committed crimes, the exact kind of crimes that many other Americans have been disgraced or gone to prison for. In order to skate her only tactic was to stall, obfuscate, and lie as she has been doing her entire career.
It was a great Friday. Go Trump!

I too am humiliated by our contemporaries of the "me" generation.

What has been cavalierly wasted in human potential and resources of all kinds is appalling, astounding and just unbelievable.

Our "Exceptionalism" has met its karma.

Voted Thursday, straight Dem as usual.

I was a child of the 1950's when there was open racism and anti-Semitism. But America was the last manufacturing nation left standing after World War 2 and there were possibilities for even white men without high school degrees. The United States seemed a hopeful place in spite the Cold War and nuclear threat.

In my teens a young President was assassinated and his replacement constructed a lie that led to Vietnam war. 58,000 of my generation died. I angry and yet optimistic as the stain of segregation was finally recognized.

As I was entering adulthood a President bombed Cambodia, beginning a civil war there that took 3 miiiion lives. The same President took the country into the swamp of his own paranoia, impeachment and resignation. Yet our democracy survived.

As I became a parent a weak Presidential was followed by a jovial fool who undermined of economic principle with the trickle down theory and became more myth than reality. Sex and tawdry details haunted another administration.

9/11 stunned our nation. Only a few were asked to sacrifice. Bush/Cheney blew up the Middle East. I raged against their stupidity. My country never learned.

Now in old age I am watching a history of the 1930's replayed. Father Coughlin is reborn in Donald Trump, the spoiled, amoral narcissist whose ignorance is proportional to his limited vocabulary . For the first time I am truly terrified for my nation. This is what my generation has given the world. Shame!

I have the following thought. Comey reasoned that if Clinton wins the election she will probably face a Republican Congress. When the existence of these e-mails became known, as it surely would, he would be blamed by Congress for remaining silent prior to the election thereby allowing Hillary to be elected. Congress would tear him to shreds.
Now, he releases the e-mails. Even if Clinton is elected, Congress will be satiated and he will be safe.
Of course, if there is any justice in the world, he will be fired on Nov. 9 regardless of the outcome of the election.
